awd_titl_txt: Closing the solar fuel cycle: Investigating organic amines and water as reversible electron donors
awd_abstract_narration:
This award in the Catalysis program supports the work of Professor Stefan Bernhard at Carnegie Mellon University. This project focuses on the development of light rechargeable batteries as a cheap, practical way to capture and store the sun's energy for powering common electronic devices. The batteries are inspired by photosynthesis in plants which drives a fuel producing reaction called reduction via oxygen generation. For functional batteries to be produced, both of these types of reactions must be optimized and then combined with forward reactions representing charging, while the back reaction of the products serves as the discharge cycle. Possible reduction reactions targeted here produce hydrogen and metal products or compounds produced from carbon dioxide. To optimize the reduction, new catalysts and light absorbers are being designed to push the limits of performance and stability. On the oxidation side, the same kind of oxygen evolution in plants has already been widely studied, but here, work looks at a different chemistry, amine oxidation, as a potentially more practical alternative for use in a battery. This unexplored process can be established as a new tool for solar energy storage.  Because this research project is aimed at a critical societal challenge, it inspires students to gain chemical knowledge and to become involved in chemical research. Moreover, the Bernhard laboratory continues to reach out to and involve researchers from underrepresented groups in the fields of science, technology and engineering. Educational activities at the undergraduate and graduate student level focus on the theme of renewable energy while outreach activities for non-scientists both educate the public on energy issues and instill excitement for science in general. 

Light to chemical energy conversion systems commonly comprise of a light-absorbing chromophore, a catalytic cycle producing reduced fuel, and a complementary oxidative cycle. Work proposed here aims to optimize these elements for unification in a solar rechargeable battery which can serve as a cheap, practical means of simultaneously capturing and storing the sun's energy. Such batteries would charge through solar driven forward reduction and oxidation while back reaction of the products would enable discharge. Work towards new batteries builds upon previous efforts in the Bernhard lab which have pioneered the use of Ir(III)-based chromophores as highly efficient drivers for photo-induced water and metal ion reduction. In the established schemes, these chromophores pass excited electrons to a reduction catalyst or substrate while receiving electrons from a sacrificial amine. This amine then undergoes irreversible C-N bond dissociation prohibiting any back electron transfer. However, translating this system to a rechargeable battery means that the amine donor must be designed to not suffer oxidation-induced degradation while still preventing back reaction. To this end, amines are being pursued with reversible electrochemistry as well as an oxidized form which is heavily stabilized via deprotonation and aromatization for prevention of back electron transfer. Initial electrochemical studies on amines pinpoint promising structures with suitable oxidation potentials. Subsequent studies in a galvanic cell then insure that the stable oxidized form of the amines can be reduced back to their original structures. Champion donors are ultimately utilized in systems where their oxidation is unified with a photo-induced reduction reaction producing metal or hydrogen fuel. Nuclear magnetic resonance and Raman spectroscopy are used to carefully monitor the fate of the amine upon illumination. While ongoing efforts are largely focused on amine oxidation, water oxidation is still a desirable counterpart for reductions in solar fuel schemes. Thus, some work is aimed at developing families of Ir(III) catalysts for water oxidation. The oxygen product of this reaction is a strong oxidant, so catalysts are being designed specifically to resist ligand oxidation for a longer lifetime.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The work funded by this award performed in the Bernhard laboratory at Carnegie Mellon University investigated and analyzed the reactivity of reagents used in light-to-chemical-energy conversions. Such processes are the foundation of natural and artificial photosynthesis and a clear understanding of the inner workings is required to photogenerate practical fuels from inexpensive and environmentally benign precursors like water or metal salts under sunlight illumination. Custom-built equipment allowed the study of thousands of photoreactions, a two orders of magnitude increase over previous work. The reactors were built from readily available parts and techniques that are commonly utilized by the Maker culture. The data management and acquisition was performed with single board computers such as Raspberry Pis and Arduinos. 3D printing, laser cutting, and CNC machining was used to build the structural components. The detection was highly parallelized and was commonly achieved by machine vision protocols. This change in chemical analysis allowed access to a highly diverse set of reaction conditions and chemical structures. Modern data science techniques were used to find and rationalize trends and patterns in this unprecedentedly large data set. One area of great interest was the development of a reactor that allowed the screening of more than 100 hydrogen-producing photochemical reactions. An example of the reactor and the result of a study is depicted below.

Light-driven, organic transformations that are commonly used to synthesize the active ingredients in pharmaceuticals were another of area funded by this award. The research used a very traditional, molecular pH-probe-based approach in a multi-well reactor setup for exploring the structure activity relationships in a set of over a thousand different Ir(III) photocatalysts. The work led to the discovery of novel ligand systems that are small organic molecules used to create a very reactive environment around the central Ir(III) ion. An example of the photographic detection technique is depicted below also.

The award used outreach activities to excite students in schools attended by above average numbers of underrepresented minorities about energy related research. Hands-on lessons on fruit/vegetable batteries taught elementary school kids about electrode materials, voltage, multimeters, and many other battery related topics.

 


Last Modified: 10/26/2021
Modified by: Stefan Bernhard

  • A pH-sensitive probe is used to screen the progress of a synthetic transformation in parallel
